byline.contributor: Eric Schmitt, Helene Cooper and Thom Shanker contributed reporting from Washington, and David Jolly from Kabul.

abstract: Internal military investigation finds that American airstrike on Doctors Without Borders hospital in Kunduz, Afghanistan, was due to 'avoidable human error' by fatigued soldiers as well as technical, mechanical and procedural problems; several service members are reportedly suspended; Doctors Without Borders calls for non-military, independent inquiry and Human Right Watch demands criminal investigation into incident.
lead_paragraph: Several service members have been suspended after an internal military investigation of the American airstrike on a Doctors Without Borders facility in Afghanistan.

headline.main: U.S. General Says Kunduz Hospital Strike Was ‘Avoidable’
headline.print_headline: U.S. General Says Hospital Strike Was ‘Avoidable’

snippet: Several service members have been suspended after an internal military investigation of the American airstrike on a Doctors Without Borders facility in Afghanistan.
